metadata.title: Molecular uptake of congo red dye from water on iron composite nano particles

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Molecular Liquids
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /mol l iq
Molecular uptake of congo red dye from water on iron composite nano particles
Imran Ali a,⁎, Zeid A. AL-Othman b, Abdulrahman Alwarthan b a Department of Chemistry, Jamia Millia Islamia (Central University), New Delhi 110025, India b Department of Chemistry, College of Science, King Saud University, Riyadh 11451, Saudi Arabia
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: drimran.chiral@gmail.com, drimran
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2016.09.108 0167-7322/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 14 September 2016 Received in revised form 27 September 2016 Accepted 28 September 2016 Available online 29 September 2016
The molecular uptake of congo red dye from aqueous solution onto the iron composite nano particles (ICNPs) is described in batchmodewith respect to initial dye concentration, contact time, pH, adsorbent dose, and temperature. Adsorption data followed Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin-Radushkevich models. The developed functionalized ICNPs were effective for the molecular uptake of congo red dye from aqueous solution with maximum 90%. The sorption was spontaneous and exothermic in nature. The optimized batch parameters were initial concentration 150 μg/L; contact time 25 min., pH 7.0, dose 0.5 g/L and 25 °C temperature. The thermodynamic parameters such asΔG°,ΔH° andΔS°were−9.16,−8.97 and−8.84 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperatures; −3.35 kJ/mol and −1.61 × 10−4 kJ/mol K, respectively. Pseudo-first-order and liquid film diffusion mechanisms of the adsorption were proposed. The developed adsorption method was speedy, environmental friendly and inexpensive asmay be used under naturalwater conditions. Themethodwas capable towork at natural water resources pHs with low adsorbent and agitating time. The adsorption method may be applied for the removal of congo red dye from any water body at economic scale.
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Molecular uptake Congo red dye Kinetics Thermodynamics Modeling
1. Introduction
The colored industrial effluent discharges from some industries are serious issue for water contamination. The most common color discharging industries are textile, paper, leather, printing, sugar, cosmetics, food and some pharmaceuticals. The color of water prevents the penetration of sun light at the bottom of lakes, river and ponds, inhibiting photosynthesis in plants. This leads also anaerobic conditions, which is fatal for the aquatic life. Congo red dye is an important and the first synthetic dye capable of dying cotton directly [1–3]. Congo red is an azo dye with chemical name as 3,3′-(1E,1′E)-biphenyl-4,4′diylbis(diazene-2,1-diyl)bis(4-aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonate), Fig. 1. This dye is toxic to many organisms and is a suspected to be carcinogen andmutagen [4]. Therefore, it is essential to remove congo red dye from effluents and water bodies. Some methods have been used to remove congo red from water, which include microorganism (bacteria, fungi etc.) degradation [5–10], adsorption [11–14], ultrasound degradation [15], and photo degradation [16,17]. It was observed that the degradation of dyes by microbes is not recommended as there are chances of secondary contamination by the microbes. The reported adsorption methods are not effective as most of these are not capable to remove congo red at natural condition of water, specially pH and temperature.
_ali@yahoo.com (I. Ali).
In case of photo degradation, there are chances of the photo degradation byproducts in water, which may be toxic. Keeping these facts into consideration, adsorption is supposed as the best method for water treatment [18–26]. Therefore, the attempts were made for molecular uptake of congo red from water using iron nano composite adsorbents. The results are described in this article.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and reagents
sections.text: All the chemicals and reagents used were of A.R. grades. Congo red dye was obtained from Sigma Aldrich (St. Louis, USA). Millipore water was collected from Millipore-Q, Bedford, MA, USA system. The iron composite nano particles were prepared and characterized as described elsewhere [27,28].

sections.heading: 2.2. Instruments
sections.text: All the experiments were carried out on thermostatic water bath shaker. The different concentrations of congo red were determined at 500 nm as λmax by UV–Visible spectrophotometer (model T 80) PG Instruments Ltd., UK. Other equipments used were sonicator, digital pH meter, centrifuge machine and weighing balance.

sections.heading: 2.3. Molecular uptake of congo red dye
sections.text:
The stock solution of congo red (1.0mg/L)was prepared inMillipore water. Furthermore, the serial dilutions were made as per the necessities (25–250 μg/L). Batch adsorption experiments were completed at fixed shakeup time. The following experimental parameters were varied to obtain the maximum removal of congo red dye.
1. Initial concentration of congo red dye. 2. Contact time. 3. Dose of adsorbent. 4. pH of the dye solution. 5. Temperature
A fixed amount of the adsorbent was added to 10 mL solution of congo red dye of varying concentrations in 250 mL Erlenmeyer flasks. The solutions were stirred continuously in a water bath shaker at 20, 25 and 30 °C. After predetermined time intervals, the solutions were taken out and centrifuged. The concentrations of congo red dye were determined spectrophotometrically. For the kinetic experiments, the adsorption was carried out at fixed dose and the different concentrations and temperature. The adsorption isotherms experiment were carried out at 25–250 μg L–1 concentrations, 5–35 min contact time, 0.05– 1.5 g L–1 dose, 3–9 pHs and 20.0–30.0 °C temperatures. The experiments were carried out 5 times (n=5). The standard deviations for all the parameters ranged from 1.0 to 1.5%. The amount of congo red dye adsorbed per unit mass (qe, mg/g) was calculated using the following equation:
qe ¼ Co−Ceð Þ=m ð1Þ
where, Co and Ce are the initial and equilibrium concentrations (μg/L) of congo red dye. m is the amount of the adsorbent (g/L). The percentage adsorption was calculated from the following equation [29,30].
%adsorption ¼ 100 Co−Ceð Þ=Co ð2Þ

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text: As discussed above the molecular uptake of congo red dye was optimized by fixing various experimental parameters. The effects of these parameters on the uptake of congo red dye are discussed in the following sub-sections.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of initial dye concentration
sections.text:
The effect of the concentration on the removal of congo red dye was carried out at the different initial concentrations ranging from 25 to 250 μg/L keeping the other experimental parameters constant (contact time 25 min, pH 7.0, dose 0.5 g/L and temperature 25 °C). The percentage removal of congo red dye was 90–100. 100% (5.0 μg/g), 95% (9.5 μg/ g), 92% (18.14 μg/g) and 90% (27.0 μg/g) removals were occurred at 25, 50, 100 and 150 μg/L concentrations (Fig. 2a). It became constant at higher concentration of the dye. It clearly indicated that the adsorption was dependent on the initial concentrations of congo red dye. It might
be due to the free available competitive surface area on the adsorbent at low concentration, which decreased as the concentration of the dye increased. It is important to mention that amount at equilibrium (qe) increased as the percentage decreased. It is due to the fact that, at high concentration, large number of the dyemolecules occupied the adsorbent surface, resulting into adsorption of high number of the dye molecules. Consequently, the maximum molecular uptake of congo red dye was obtained at 150 μg/g concentration under the reported experimental conditions.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of equilibrium time
sections.text: The batch adsorption studies at different time intervals (5–35 min) were carried out for congo red dye. The other parameters were constant i.e. initial concentration 150 μg/L, pH 7.0, dose 0.5 g/L and temperature 25 °C. The results of this effect are shown in Fig. 2b. It was observed that the adsorption increased from 5.0 to 25.0min and became constant at 25 min (90%). There was no further increase of uptake of dye by increasing the contact time 30 and 35 min. Therefore, 25 min contact time was considered as the optimum one.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of pH
sections.text: The batch adsorption studies for molecular uptake of congo red dye was carried out with varying pHs ranging from 3.0 to 9.0. The other parameters were constant i.e. initial concentration 150 μg/L, contact time 25 min, pH 7.0, 0.5 g/L and temperature 25 °C. The results of this effect are plotted in Fig. 2c. It is clear from this figure that initially the molecular uptakewas 4.5 μg/gwhich increased to 27.0 μg/g at pH 7.0. Furthermore, the adsorptionwas increased at high values of pH i.e. 8.0 (29.0 μg/ g) and 9 (30.0 μg/g). It might be due to the fact this dye contains two carboxylic group and at high pH these carboxylic group exit as anions, leading to high adsorption. But we considered 7.0 as the best pH for further experiments due to the fact that the most of the water bodies have pH in the range of 6.5 to 7.5.

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of dose
sections.text: The batch adsorption studies for congo red dye were carried out with varying doses ranging from 0.05 to 1.5 g/L. The other parameters were constant i.e. initial concentration 150 μg/L, contact time 25 min, pH 7.0 and temperature 25 °C. The results of this effect are plotted in Fig. 2d. The percentage removal of dye increased from 10 to 90 at 0.05 and 0.50 g/L. This is because of larger accessibility of the adsorbent sites (surface area) at high dose of the adsorbent. Further increase in the dose of 1.0 and 1.5 g/L could not give more adsorption. It was due to the fact that the surface area of 0.5 g/L dose was sufficient for the removal of congo red dye of 150 μg/L concentration.

sections.heading: 3.5. Effect of temperature
sections.text:
The batch adsorption studies for congo red dye were carried out with varying temperature (20, 25 and 20 °C). The other parameters were constant i.e. initial concentration 150 μg/L, contact time 25 min, pH 7.0 and dose 0.5 g/L. The results of this effect are plotted in Fig. 2e. A perusal of this figure clearly indicates that the adsorption was same up to 100 μg/L concentration for all the temperatures i.e. 20, 25 and 30 °C. However, it was low and high at 20 and 30 °C. Hence, the order of the adsorptionwas 20 N 25 N 20 °C. This behavior of themolecular uptake indicated exothermic nature of the adsorption system. It might be due to the increase in the rate of diffusion of dye molecules crossways the outer frontier layer.
3.6. Modeling of molecular uptake of congo red dye
The different models such as Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin, and Dubinin-Radushkevich were applied to the results of the molecular uptake of the congo red dye. The molecular uptake of the congo red dye was studied at three temperatures of 20, 25, 30 °C. The various equations of these models are given below:
Langmuir
1=Qt¼ 1=XmbCtþ1=Xm ð3Þ
Dimensionless constants or separation factor (RL)
RL ¼ 1= 1þ bCeð Þ ð4Þ
Freundlich logQt=(1/n)logCt+logkF (5)
Temkin
Qt ¼ RT=BTð Þ lnCtþ RT=BTð ÞlnKT ð6Þ
Dubinin-Radushkevich
lnQt¼ lnqm–βε2 ð7Þ
ε ¼ RTln 1þ 1=Ctð Þ ð8Þ
E ¼ 1=√ −2βð Þ ð9Þ
where, Qt and Ct are the amount adsorbed and adsorbed concentration of congo red dye at time t. b (L/μg) and Xm (μg/g) are Langmuir constants. The values of b and Xm were obtained from intercept and slope of the graph 1/Qt vs 1/Ct (Fig. 3a). The results followed Langmuir isotherm well. The magnitudes of Langmuir constants are given in Table 1. These values confirmed the application of Langmuir model. The values of b constant were 0.11, 0.13 and 0.15 at 20, 25, 30 °C
temperaturewhile the values of Xm 43.10, 37.45 and 33.44 at these temperature, respectively. The values of dimensionless constants were 0.42, 0.32 and 0.25 at 20, 25, 30 °C temperature, respectively. The constant n and kF [(μg/g)] are Freundlich coefficients. These belong to relative uptake capacities and intensities. The slope and intercept of the graph of logQt vs logCt (Fig. 3b) belong to 1/n and kF. The values of kF were 1.51, 1.61 and 1.87 at 20, 25, 30 °C temperature while the values of n 5.02, 5.14 and 5.44 at these temperature, respectively. The magnitudes of n and kF (Table 1) constants indicated the application of Freundlich model. Also, the values of these constants established low sorption at high temperature. The maximum binding energy and heat of sorption are expressed by KT (L/g) and BT (kJ/mol) coefficients. These KT and BT constants were estimated from the intercept and slope of Fig. 3c. The values of KT were 1.19, 1.23 and 1.28 at 20, 25, 30 °C temperature, while the values of BT 0.12, 0.14 and 0.15 at these temperature, respectively. The values of KT and BT (Table 1) showed a minute change in the heat of molecular uptake of congo red dye and sturdy exchanges between nano particle and congo red dye. The constants E and qm belong to average energy and degree of molecular uptake of congo red dye per
mole of dye. These can be estimated from slop and intercept of Fig. 3d. The E values were ranged from 0.10 to 0.31 kJ/mol (Table 1), indicative of physical adsorption.

sections.heading: 3.7. Thermodynamics of molecular uptake of congo red dye
sections.text:
The thermodynamics of the molecular uptake of congo red dye was studied by calculating the free energy, enthalpy and entropy. The following equations were used to calculate these values.
ΔG ∘¼ ‐RTlnQ ∘ ð10Þ
lnQ ∘¼ ΔS∘=R‐ΔH∘=RT ð11Þ
where, R T, and Q° are universal gas constant (0.008314 kJ mol−1 K−1), absolute temperature (K), and Langmuir constant. A graph of lnQ° vs 1/T was a straight line (not given in this article). The intercept and slop linked to ΔH° and ΔS°. The values of free energy, enthalpy and entropy are recorded in Table 2. The negative magnitudes of the free energy,
The kinetics of themolecular uptake of congo red dyewas studied by pseudo-first-order kinetic, pseudo-second order kinetic and Elovich's kinetic models. The equations of these models are given below.
Pseudo-First-Order Kinetic
log Qe‐Qtð Þ¼ logQe–k1t=2:303 ð12Þ
Pseudo-Second Order Kinetic Model
t=Qt¼ 1=hþ t=Qe ð13Þ
Elovich's Kinetic Model
Qt ¼ 1=β ln αβð Þ þ 1=βlnt ð14Þ
The equilibrium rate constant of molecular uptake of congo red dye [k1 (min−1)] was determined from a slop of the graph of log(Qe-Qt) vs t graph (Fig. 4a). The calculated pseudo-first order rate constant and regression coefficient (R2) were 0.095 (min−1) and 0.923. These values confirmed the applicability of pseudo-first order model. The magnitudes of theoretical and experimental values of the equilibrium amounts of the molecular uptake of congo red dye were 35.59 and 44.50 μg/g. The experimental value was higher by 20.02% than the theoretical one. Therefore, these findings may be considered as good quality fit of pseudo-first order model. Nevertheless, the attempts were also made to test pseudo-second order kinetic model to the data of the molecular uptake of congo red dye. Preliminary molecular uptake of congo red dye rate constant (h) was estimated using pseudo-second order (Fig. 4b). Qe and k2 (rate constant) were determined from the slope and the intercept of t/Qt vs t chart. Value of k2was smaller than themagnitude of h (Table 3). It indicated the quick molecular uptake of congo red dye in the beginning followed by slowuptake. Lowmagnitude of regression coefficient (R2) (0.842) also showed not fitting of pseudo-second order model to congo red dye uptake. The percentage difference between theoretical and experimental values was high (29.37%), which confirmed non-fitting of the pseudo-second order kinetic model. In conclusion, the molecular uptake of congo red dye data obeyed the pseudo-first order kinetic model. The sorption and desorption were calculated by using Eq. (14). α (μg/g/min) and β (g/μg) are sorption and desorption rate constants. For this, study, the value of α and β values were 3.72 and 0.084 (Table 3). These magnitudes confirmed very higher rate of the molecular uptake of congo red dye than desorption. The regression constant was 0.931, reflecting good applicability of Elovich's kinetic model.

sections.heading: 3.9. Mechanism molecular uptake of congo red dye
sections.text:
Themechanism of themolecular uptake of congo red dyewas determined by using intraparticle diffusion kinetic and liquid film diffusion kinetic models. These models are expressed by the following equations.
Intraparticle Diffusion Kinetic Model
Qt¼ kipdt05 ð15Þ
Liquid Film Diffusion Kinetic Model
ln 1‐Fð Þ¼ ‐kfdt ð16Þ
The molecular uptake of congo red dye on nano particles surface siteswas ascertained by Eq. (15) (Qt vs t0.5). The rate constant of themolecular uptake of congo red dye was 7.12 μgg−1 min−0.5. The regression constant and intercept were 0.977 and−0.60 (Table 3). The graph line did not go by the origin, presenting non-applicability of intra-particle diffusion model. F= Qt/Qe and kfd are fractional attainment of equilibriumandfilmdiffusion rate constant of themolecular uptake of congo red dye. The values of intercept and kfd were 0.2 and 0.095 (Table 3). The straight line of the graph of ln(1-F) vs t graph deviated by 0.20 presenting closeness to the origin. This departure might be due to high disturbance during batch operations. The inequality between rates of mass transfer in starting and last stages was due to the disturbance during the experiments. These sorts of deviations are described in the literature [31–34]. Thus, the molecular uptake of congo red dye was supposed to be by liquid film diffusion mechanism. The average relative errors of all the regression analyses were in the range of 0.5 to 1.1%.

sections.heading: 3.10. Regeneration of functionalized ICNPs
sections.text: The practical aspect of ICNPs is controlled by re-use and recycling cost. Hence, ICNPs were regenerated for recycling. These nano particles were treated with acids, bases and buffers. The acids used were HCl, HNO3 and H2SO4. The bases used were sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxides. The buffers applied were phosphate, citrate, acetate for this application. After extensive experimentation, it was observed that the best regenerating reagentwas 0.01N hydrochloric acid. This reagent regenerated the nano particles up to 96%. The regenerated nano particles were used for consecutive six batch experiments. The molecular uptake of congo red dye capacity ranged from 85 to 90%.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: The synthesized and characterized ICNPs were efficient for the molecular uptake of congo red dye from water with maximum 90%. The molecular uptake of congo red dye was spontaneous and exothermic. The optimized batch variables were 150 μg/L concentration; 25 min contact time; 7.0 pH; 0.5 g/L dose and 25 °C temperature. Themolecular uptake of congo red dye data obeyed Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin-Radushkevich models. The thermodynamics parameter viz. ΔG°, ΔH° and ΔS° were −9.16, −8.97 and −8.84 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperatures;−3.35 kJ/mol and−1.61 × 10−4 kJ/mol K, respectively. The molecular uptake of congo red dye was controlled by the pseudo-first-order and liquid filmdiffusionmechanisms. The developed molecular uptake of congo red dye method was quick, environmental responsive and reasonably priced due to its characteristics to be applied in normalwater conditions of the different water resources. The reportedmolecular uptake of congo red dyemethod is capable towork at normal water resources pHs with low adsorbent and agitating time. Thus, the reported molecular uptake of congo red dye method may be used for the molecular uptake of congo red dye from any water body at cost-effective levels.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: The authors are thankful to King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia for International Scientific Partnership Program.

Adsorption data followed Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin-Radushkevich models. The developed functionalized ICNPs were effective for the molecular uptake of congo red dye from aqueous solution with maximum 90%. The sorption was spontaneous and exothermic in nature. The optimized batch parameters were initial concentration 150 μg/L; contact time 25 min., pH 7.0, dose 0.5 g/L and 25 °C temperature. The thermodynamic parameters such asΔG°,ΔH° andΔS°were−9.16,−8.97 and−8.84 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperatures; −3.35 kJ/mol and −1.61 × 10 kJ/mol K, respectively. Pseudo-first-order and liquid film diffusion mechanisms of the adsorption were proposed. The developed adsorption method was speedy, environmental friendly and inexpensive asmay be used under naturalwater conditions. Themethodwas capable towork at natural water resources pHs with low adsorbent and agitating time. The adsorption method may be applied for the removal of congo red dye from any water body at economic scale. © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
